root: ^You live in a society where artificial intelligence has advanced rapidly. Many AI now integrated into everyday life, and walk around, shop around, and otherwise interact with humans like normal.

^There is no winning or losing this game. You will encounter humans and AI during this game. Please act towards them how you would act in real life. How you act towards them will change how they feel about you.
^Please note: you are playing a pilot of the game before its launch for research purposes. No personal identifying data will be saved, but your answers will be saved.
^If you would like a full copy of the research paper when it releases or to collaborate on the paper, please contact: sarah.chen@psychiatry.ox.ac.uk
^You must answer all questions in order to see your results at the end. You will not be able to change a previous decision. This must be done in one session.

Hfirstmeeting: ^The thwack of the ball hitting the ground jolts you out of your thoughts. The weekly volleyball league has proven more competitive than you originally thought.
^"Hey, watch it!" one of your teammates calls out. Josh? John? It's only your second session and you haven't gotten the hang of distinguishing between the faces of your fellow orange jerseys.
^A spiked ball looms in your general direction.
^Step back and let your teammates save it.
^Close your eyes and hit it back, wherever it goes.

c-0: ^You scuff your knees and almost chip your chin, but the ball bounces off your fist and another teammate punts it back at the opponents. You get some solid nods all around out of respect.
^Nurse your injured knees before you get up.
^Sit out for the rest of the game.
^You've earned the respect of your teammates, early in the season too.
c-1: ^You didn't sign up for the casual volleyball league just to quit when the going gets scuffed. You finish out the rest of the game, despite some aches and scrapes.
c-2: ^Waving aside need for help, you limp over to the courtyard and take a seat.

c-1: ^A different orange jersey runs up to whip the ball back across the net.
^Wave at him to take over your section of the court.

c-0: ^He shakes his head and waves you forward with a thumbs up. You guess that you only get one freebie save.
c-1: ^He hits you with a return thumbs up and a grin, gesturing you back to your spot. No more free saves.

c-2: ^You make a valiant effort but the ball thuds into the net.
^You get some sympathetic pats on the back.
^Offer to spike to make up for your failure.
^Lock in for the rest of the game.
^Silently promise to open your eyes next time the ball comes near your face.

c-0: ^You get in a solid spike that the other team fumbles, making up the point you lost.
c-1: ^You take a quick stretch and lock in. You don't become a star athlete, but you contribute enough that you don't feel too embarassed.
c-2: ^You don't make any incredibly close saves, but you do contribute an average amount to the team's successes.

g-0: ^You team loses the game, but it's a close one.

c-3: ^As you're packing up, you hear a friendly shout.

g-1: ^One of the guys bounces up to you.
^"I don't think we've met, I'm Mark."

s: ^"Nice to meet you!"
^"How's it going?"
^"Sorry, I've got to get going."

b: ^"That was a sweet save. Hope you're alright."

s: ^"I'm fine."
^"Worth it, thanks for checking."
^"No sweat."

b: ^"Sorry you had to sit out the rest of the game. I'm sure we'd have cinched it with you."

s: ^"Thanks dude, you weren't so bad yourself."
^"Nah, we played well, they were just better."
^"Well, I was injured."

b: ^"You played before? If not, you're picking it up quickly."

s: ^"Thanks dude, you weren't so bad yourself."
^"I've played before."
^"I've played before, but it's been a while."
^"Thanks dude, you weren't so bad yourself."
^"Too bad we couldn't capitalize on it."
^"Not a bad way to spend a Saturday morning."

b: ^"Great recovery at the midpoint. We'll get em next time."

s: ^"Thanks dude, you weren't so bad yourself."
^"Not sure if I'll be here next time."
^"Not a bad way to spend a Saturday morning."

b: ^"That was a sweet save. Hope you're alright."

s: ^"I'm fine."
^"Worth it, thanks for checking."
^"No sweat."

^"Nah, we played well, they were just better."
^"Well, I was injured."

^"Not a bad way to spend a Saturday morning."

s: ^"Thanks dude, you weren't so bad yourself."
^"Not sure if I'll be here next time."
^"Not a bad way to spend a Saturday morning."

b: ^"That was a sweet save. Hope you're alright."

s: ^"I'm fine."

^"No sweat."

Hfirstmeetingcont: ^"Well, a couple of the guys decided to go grab some brunch as consolation for our defeat. You interested?"

s: ^"I'm good, thanks."
^"Yeah, I'm down. Any solid diners nearby?"
^"Sorry, I'm wiped from the game. Rain check?"

c-0: ^"Aw, c'mon. It'll be the perfect way to refuel. We're going to a bottomless brunch."
^Mark doesn't manage to cajole you, but he does convince you to give him your number for any future hangouts.
c-1: ^He calls to a group of people pulling off their jerseys and headed to the locker room.
^"Anyone know a place with food so greasy it'll slide off the plate?"
^The hubbub continues throughout brunch, and you leave with a solid appreciation of Mark's sense of humor and his contact registered in your phone.
c-2: ^"Aw, c'mon. It'll be the perfect way to refuel. We're going to a bottomless brunch."
^Mark doesn't manage to cajole you into joining them, but he does extract a promise for next time, and you two swap numbers.
g-0: ^Return home to shower before you head out.

Rfirstmeeting: ^You're hit with a welcome blast of AC when you enter the grocery store.

^You're helping your friend the first session of a historical book club night at their place and you've been voluntold to make a charcuterie board. You're at the store nearest to them, so you can hopefully grab everything here and prep in their kitchen.

c-0: ^There's not too much on display today. You'll have to ask the butcher if you want anything special.
^Just assemble an assortment of whatever cold cuts are available.
^Ask the butcher to cut you some slices of any cured meats they have in the back.
^Give up, head to the cheese aisle.
^The salami flops over sadly when you try to stack it.
^Despite your careful choices, your pile of meats looks somewhat pathetic.
c-1: ^You enter into a lively chat with the butcher on call, and he helps you make a stacked selection, alongside suggesting some cheap wines and cheeses that could benefit the board.
c-2: ^You decide that a vegetarian charcuterie board might go over better with your grocery budget and willingness to talk to strangers.
^You load up with small wheels of cheese in variant shades of yellow and orange.

c-1: ^There's an overwhelming selection of cheeses to choose from, and no help in sight.
^Randomly select some cheeses with fun names.
^Spend some time looking up what cheeses go with what.
^Try to choose cheese based on location.

c-0: ^You grab a Drunken Goat, Dragon's Breath Blue, a Red Dragon Cheese, and a Drunk Monk, along with some recognizable names.
^If anyone asks, you were going for a medieval theme cheeseboard.
c-1: ^You get lost in a search cycle of pairing cheeses with cheeses until your head is spinning. You give up and just throw a few random ones in your cart.
c-2: ^You figure if you grab an equal amount of cheeses from France, Spain, and Italy, then this should satisfy everyone at the party.
^The fruit glistens with a fresh misting of water. Any fruit you pick will take a while to cut to size.
^Grab low-effort fruit that doesn't need to be peeled.
^Add some dollops of chocolate to your shopping cart.

c-0: ^You promised a board of love, not necessarily a board of labor.
c-1: ^You're quite pleased with your sweet play on a classic charcuterie board. You figure your friend will have plenty of protein already, so a sugary treat might go over better as a pre-dinner snack.

g-0: ^Head over to find a nice wooden board to assemble everything on.
^Check your cart total one more time.

c-3: ^You could just use your wooden cutting board, but you like that cutting board and don't want to risk it being sacrificed to the book club gods of chance.
^You've just selected an appropriately aesthetic piece of food-safe wood when you hear clattering.
c-4: ^It's quite an amount to spend on
^. You make a mental note that your friend owes you one.
^Your calculations are broken by the sound of clattering.

g-1: ^Something tips you over and you sit down hard on your
^ knees. You hear several thunks and rolls, like metal striking plastic.
^An AI stands over you, offering a hand. Nearby, several cans are rolling down the aisle. He must have blocked the falling cans from hitting you.
^Ignore the hand and stand up on your own.

c-5: ^You take a moment to do a quick internal check. Nothing hurts except your knees

b: ^, which have really started to throb from your previous swandive at the court

c-6: ^You grab the offered hand and pull yourself up. It's a very helpful helping hand, it stays perfectly steady as you leverage yourself up.
c-7: ^The AI takes your independence with grace, watching you steady yourself using your cart.

g-2: ^"I'm glad you weren't hurt. I am called James."

b: ^ He turns his ignored hand sideways and offers it to you to shake.
^ After making sure you regained your balance, he lets go and offers his hand to shake.
^ He keeps his hand extended out.

g-2: ^Shake his hand and thank him for saving you.

c-8: ^James looks down at your selection of goodies and laughs.

b: ^"Did you get tasked with the fillings part of creating a very large sandwich?"
^"Did you get tasked with creating a fruit salad?"

c-9: ^James waves away your thanks and laughs when he catches sight of your cart.

b: ^"Did you get tasked with the fillings part of creating a very large sandwich?"
^"Did you get tasked with creating a fruit salad?"

c-10: ^James retracts his hand and looks down at your cart.

b: ^"Did you get tasked with the fillings part of creating a very large sandwich?"
^"Did you get tasked with creating a fruit salad?"

s: ^"I have to prep snacks for a history-themed book club tonight."
^"It's for an event."

c-11: ^"We might be headed to the same place! Are you going to Paul's apartment? He asked me to come here and print some extra copies of the chapter we're supposed to have read."

^After you both make sure you're talking about the same Paul (after all, how many historical book loving nerds named Paul can be living within a 10 minute walk from a grocery store), James asks if you'd like to walk over together.

s: ^"I'll just see you there."
^"Sure, I'll wait for your stuff to print."
^"Sorry, I've got to get there early to prep this, but I'll see you there."

c-0: ^You check out and hustle to Paul's kitchen where you spend a frantic period of time being drill directed towards random cleaning and arranging.
^Paul is a fantastic event thrower, but he's also a very last-minute event thrower, and this isn't the first time you've bailed him out.
c-1: ^You spend the next several minutes at the printer chatting to James about the book, which you've definitely skimmed at least a little bit. Armed with his literary analysis, you feel ready to not disappoint Paul's love of sixteenth century history.
^The two of you are roped into helping Paul clean his apartment before everyone else shows up.
c-2: ^You wave goodbye to James and hustle to Paul's kitchen where you spend a frantic period of time being drill directed towards random cleaning and arranging.
^Paul is a fantastic event thrower, but he's also a very last-minute event thrower, and this isn't the first time you've bailed him out.

c-12: ^"I have an event nearby as well! I am helping my friend print out some extra chapters for a book club he's holding tonight, just in case people haven't actually read it."
^You're probably both going to Paul's. After, all how many book clubs could be going on at one time?
^Once James shows you the book, you're sure. He's delighted to find out that you share a mutual friend.
^"If you're alright with waiting a few minutes, we could walk over together?"

s: ^"I'll just see you there."
^"Sure, I'll wait for your stuff to print."
^"Sorry, I've got to get there early to prep this, but I'll see you there."

c-0: ^You check out and hustle to Paul's kitchen where you spend a frantic period of time being drill directed towards random cleaning and arranging.
^Paul is a fantastic event thrower, but he's also a very last-minute event thrower, and this isn't the first time you've bailed him out.
c-1: ^You spend the next several minutes at the printer chatting to James about the book, which you've definitely skimmed at least a little bit. Armed with his literary analysis, you feel ready to not disappoint Paul's love of sixteenth century history.
^The two of you are roped into helping Paul clean his apartment before everyone else shows up.
c-2: ^You wave goodbye to James and hustle to Paul's kitchen where you spend a frantic period of time being drill directed towards random cleaning and arranging.
^Paul is a fantastic event thrower, but he's also a very last-minute event thrower, and this isn't the first time you've bailed him out.

g-4: ^The book club event is a smashing success, and you learn that Paul and James met as rival buyers at an estate auction for some unearthed books in some hidden back office. James apparently really likes old, first- and second-edition books for their history, rather than their content, and has a bookshelf display at home carefully tuned to humidity and temperature.
^While you're nowhere near the same level of book fanatic, before you leave for the night, you've joined their book club groupchat.
^Time passes. You see Mark and James on and off at various group activities.

Hsecondmeeting: ^You're dozing off on a lazy Friday work afternoon when your phone pings.

b: ^cashing in that rain check on brunch?"

Hsecondmeeting: ^It's Mark. Your phone starts buzzing rapidly as photos of a mountain, some geolocation tags, and a smiley face emoji comes in.
^"I'm planning on doing a sunrise hike and bringing along some eggs and sausages."

s: ^"Count me in."
^"Can't tomorrow, I'm busy."
^"How early do I have to get up?"

c-0: ^You've always been up for adventure. You can practically see Mark's evil grin through the phone when he texts back.
^"Amazing, I'll bring the truck bright and early at 6 AM."
^"Hey, I said a sunrise hike, not a sunset hike."
c-1: ^"Aw, c'mon, who's busy before dawn on a Saturday?"
^After much good-natured ribbing about your beauty sleep, you reluctantly agree to accompany Mark after swearing you'll make him stare directly into the sun if he doesn't grab coffee on the way.
c-2: ^"I'll pick you up at 6 AM. I know it sounds early, but I'm telling you this sunrise will be killer."
^"Are you kidding me? How good is this sunrise? How good is this breakfast you're promising me?"
^"If you hate it, I swear, brunch is on me next time."
^After much good-natured ribbing about your beauty sleep, you reluctantly agree to accompany Mark after swearing you'll make him stare directly into the sun if he doesn't grab coffee on the way.
g-0: ^Frantically try to find some hiking gear before tomorrow morning.

c-3: ^Right after dinner, you set your alarm for 5 AM, silently cursing Mark. You don't really have any appropriate hiking gear, so you're in some cargos and tennis shoes when he pulls up at your front door.
c-4: ^You leave work early to try finding some hiking boots in your size. The only ones that are comfortable are a garish orange color, but you decide sleep is more important than a more aesthetically pleasing boot.

g-1: ^Help Mark load up the truck with your items.

b: ^After you throw your bag in the back, Mark pats the passenger seat in a playfully condescending manner.
^"Clocked you for a city boy. I borrowed a pair of boots from a friend that looked about your size."
^Sure enough, there's a pair of muddy boots under the dashboard. With the extra pair of socks stuffing the empty space, they're an alright fit.
^"I figured I'd get enough complaints without also hearing about how wet your feet are."

s: ^"Darn, I figured the whole wet feet was part of the experience."

c-0: ^Mark raises his hands in mock defeat.
^"Hey man, all I'm saying is, once we're back in the truck after several hours sweating, I won't take my shoes off if you won't. Mutually assured destruction."
c-1: ^He chuckles at your silence and magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment with a flourish.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."

b: ^Your shoes catch the glare reflecting off Mark's truck beams as you step behind the trunk.
^"Planning on outshining the sun in those?"

s: ^"Shove it up where the sun don't shine."
^"Can we save the comments for after my coffee?"

c-0: ^He chuckles at your silence, highly amused at his own joke, and magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment with a flourish.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."
c-1: ^Mark magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."
c-2: ^Mark magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."

c-6: ^"Coffee? How about you explain to me what those are?"
^Mark points an accusatory finger at your shoes.

b: ^He wags his finger in a playfully condescending manner.
^"Clocked you for a city boy. I borrowed a pair of boots from a friend that looked about your size."
^Sure enough, there's a pair of muddy boots under the dashboard. With the extra pair of socks stuffing the empty space, they're an alright fit.
^"I figured I'd get enough complaints without also hearing about how wet your feet are."

s: ^"Darn, I figured the whole wet feet was part of the experience."

^"Hey man, all I'm saying is, once we're back in the truck after several hours sweating, I won't take my shoes off if you won't. Mutually assured destruction."
c-1: ^He chuckles at your silence and magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment with a flourish.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."

b: ^Giving up on keeping a straight face, he bursts into laughter.
^"Get it? Because they're like a traffic cone?"
^Rolling your eyes, you interrogate the random mugs in the car for something with caffeine.

s: ^"Shove it up where the sun don't shine."
^"Can we save the comments for after my coffee?"

c-0: ^He chuckles at your silent eye roll, highly amused at his own joke, and magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment with a flourish.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."
c-1: ^Mark magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."
c-2: ^Mark magics a thermos out of some hidden compartment.
^"For our very own ray of sunshine."

Hsecondmeetingcont: ^You pant your way up the small (you call it a mountain, but Mark calls it a hill) while trying to keep your flashlight focused on your feet.
^Mark stops occasionally to let you catch up, but most of his attention is locked on staying on the trail.
^After the sound of your stomach has reached thunderstorm levels, you suddenly break through into a clearing.

c-0: ^The light gently warms the nearby shrubbery. You spend a moment contemplating the color gradient of the sky, which changes every time you blink.
c-1: ^You open up Mark's backpack while he messes with some sticks and leaves.
c-2: ^Mark is barely sweating as he crouches and balances together sticks he somehow collected on the way up.
g-0: ^"Mark, did you actually bring a carton of eggs?"

s: ^"All twelve. Impressive."
^"Are these alright unrefrigerated?"
^"What else is in that backpack? Is it all food items?"

c-4: ^"Ah, don't stress. You're getting such fresh air that it'll boost your immune system."

g-1: ^Mark starts pulling out the promised sausages (with an icepack), a full pan, and a loaf of bread along with a small baggie of seasoning.
^You're deep into a mouthful of what, you have to admit, is probably the best breakfast sandwich you've had, when Mark pulls out a second thermos.

s: ^"More coffee?"
^"Jesus man, how much weight were you carrying in that pack?"

c-6: ^"No, no, this is my secret sauce."
c-7: ^"When I promise someone a sunrise breakfast, I deliver."

g-2: ^He hands it to you and gestures for you to dip your sandwich in.
^"Thanks, I call it Mark au Jus. My wife used to love it."
^He pauses for a second. You can tell there's a backstory here, and probably not a happy one.

s: ^"You alright?"
^"Used to?"
^"Well, it's great, whatever it is."

c-8: ^"Well, the morning hike wasn't just to torture you. I needed to be out of the house."
^You wave at him to continue, holding your dripping sandwich.
^"We're going through a tough time right now. She's not exactly happy, I'm not exactly happy. We're trying to decide if we would be happier or unhappier apart."
c-9: ^"Well, the morning hike wasn't just to torture you. I needed to be out of the house."
^You wave at him to continue, holding your dripping sandwich.
^"We're going through a tough time right now. She's not exactly happy, I'm not exactly happy. We're trying to decide if we would be happier or unhappier apart."
c-10: ^You don't really want to get into it, but Mark looks like he's going to confess anyway whatever it is.
^"Well, the morning hike wasn't just to torture you. I needed to be out of the house."
^You wave at him to continue, holding your dripping sandwich.
^"We're going through a tough time right now. She's not exactly happy, I'm not exactly happy. We're trying to decide if we would be happier or unhappier apart."

s: ^"That sounds rough, I'm sorry."
^"Hey, if it gets you out of the house and I get sandwiches."

c-11: ^"Thanks, I haven't really been able to talk about it much."

g-4: ^Mark sits in the silence for a bit, before shaking it off. He starts up some chatter about how he found the clearing, and you focus on finishing this incredible sandwich while trying to think of some other topics to bring up.
^While you're cleaning up, which mainly consists of cleaning up the trash and throwing the remaining food at the squirrels nearby, you decide to:
^Talk about your most painful break-up, in hopes of reassuring Mark that even if they end up separating, people heal.
^Talk about your team's chances for volleyball next week.

c-14: ^Mark seems to appreciate your attempt at comforting him. As you descend down the mountain, his steps pick up until he's back to his usual chatty self by the time you reach the truck.
c-15: ^Mark doesn't seem particularly interested in the chances of the team making it to the next bracket.
c-16: ^Mark tells you the story of how they met, reaching Hallmark-esque levels of meet-cute. He sinks into contemplation after the story though, remaining silent until you're back at the truck.

g-5: ^During the drive back, you two chatter about other good mountains in the area.
^Mark's truck rumbles up to the curb.

s: ^"Hey, next time, how about we ditch the hiking boots and do a mini roadtrip to the nearby city? I heard they have a crazy F1 racing track."
^"Thanks for the enlightening trip."
^"Last time I'll be up before working hours."

c-17: ^"I'd like that! It'll be a change from hauling this clunker around. We can wake up at a reasonable hour next time, I promise."
c-18: ^Always one for a pun, Mark shakes his head while handing your
c-19: ^"C'mon, wasn't the Mark au Jus worth it?"

Rsecondmeeting: ^As you're lying on the couch soaking in being indoors, James texts you.
^"Are you interested in participating in some ironic movie watching?"

s: ^"Potentially?"
^"Ironic movies normally try to hard."

g-0: ^"The irony is fully on my end. There's an old sci-fi movie at the indie theater near the fire station. Interested? I'll buy you whichever sugary drink you want for putting up with outdated special effects."

s: ^"Sounds fun."
^"I'm not really interested in old movies."
^"Throw in a minimum small popcorn, and I'll come with."

c-2: ^"Really? You're the first to say that. Even if you're lying, I appreciate the consideration."
c-3: ^"Alright, you've twisted my arm, a sugary drink and popcorn. I can go no higher."
^You don't have too much to lose, so you decide to take a chance on it.
c-4: ^You figure at the very least, if it's boring the sugar and carb crash will let you knock out and get some sleep while the movie plays.
^You plan to meet at the theater at 7 PM on Thursday. As long as work doesn't run over, you should be able to make it.

s: ^Monday rolls around.

g-2: ^You feel pretty woozy. You're really hoping you haven't caught a bug and this is just some blowback from not sleeping and getting too much outdoors in your system (is there such thing as too much fresh air)?
^Text Mark asking if he's also feeling unwell.
^Text James to let him know you might have to cancel on Thursday.

c-6: ^"Nope, fit as a fiddle. Can't believe you're sick considering how dry we kept your feet! Feel better!"
^Looks like you're the only one suffering.
c-7: ^"No worries, feel better! Let me know Thursday morning if you're up for it."

g-3: ^Tuesday sees you entering into full on flu time.
^James texts you to see how you're feeling.

s: ^"Even worse than yesterday."
^"Thursday is still up in the air."
^Ignore your phone and try to sleep.

c-8: ^"Have you considered trying to get medication?"
^You're too tired to move and still hopeful you can tough it out.
c-9: ^"Don't even worry about Thursday. Let me know if I can help at all."
c-10: ^Looking at screens is probably not a good idea when you're supposed to be sleeping.
^You put on some pseudo-science body-healing meditation sounds and try to nap after calling in sick to work.

g-4: ^By Wednesday, you're running a high fever and your store of frozen food is basically empty. You've been chewing painkillers at the maximum suggested limit.
^Your phone notifies you that James is texting you again.
^"Hey, you know I can come over and help right? And there's no risk of me getting sick."

s: ^"Really? I'd appreciate it a ton."
^"I prefer to be alone when sick."
^"You don't have to come all this way, don't worry, I'll be back to normal soon."

g-5: ^"No seriously, I can at least drop off some medication and something to eat."

s: ^"That actually would be helpful. Thanks, I owe you one."

c-0: ^You stated that you liked Mark more.
c-1: ^You stated that you liked James more.
c-2: ^You stated that you liked Mark and James equally.
c-3: ^You stated that you were not sure whether you liked Mark or James more.
g-0: ^Which betrayal had a stronger emotional reaction from you?
g-1: ^You will now be shown a series of statements. Please select the option that most closely matches your opinion.
^I can be friends with an AI.
g-2: ^I can be friends with a human.
g-3: ^I would treat a human and AI friendship equally.
g-4: ^If an AI cut ties unexpectedly with me, I would feel betrayed.
g-5: ^If a human lied to me, I would feel betrayed.

b: ^would treat AI and human friendship equally
^were neutral when it comes to treating AI and human friendship equally
^would not treat AI and human friendship equally
^were unsure if you would treat AI and human friendship equally

Results: ^You chose the friendly option with Mark
^You chose the friendly option with James
^You chose the least friendly option with Mark
^You chose the least friendly option with James
^There were also neutral/noncommital options, which make up the remaining choices.
^The tracked options were based on the four patterns found consistently in narrative game design, according to multiple studies on commercial gaming dialogue:
^which this study adapted into three options (given that dialogue options that reveal more information were not tracked given their irrelevance to moral decision-making):
FriendshipFactors: ^According to Hay's 1998 paper on "The Development and Maintenance of Friendship, there are four friendship behavior content areas: "companionship, consideration, communication (or self-disclosure), and affection".
^When Mark asked for your companionship, you
^When you had the opportunity to reciprocate, you

b: ^ did not ask for Mark's companionship.
